simple_results: [{"detection_name": "Field Suggestions Enabled", "detection": "vulnerable", "category": "Information Disclosure", "description": "Field suggestions enabled - potential information disclosure", "evidence": "Found \"did you mean\" in error message - field suggestions are enabled"}]
llm_results: [{"detection_name": "LLM: field_suggestions", "detection": "potential", "category": "Unknown", "description": "The GraphQL API returns helpful 'Did you mean ...' suggestions in error messages that reveal actual field names in the schema (e.g., completed, username). This is a field_suggestions/information-disclosure issue: an attacker can use these suggestions to enumerate accurate schema field names and shape subsequent queries, facilitating more targeted data discovery or abuse. While this does not itself indicate SQLi, XSS, SSRF, or command injection, it increases attack surface by exposing internal schema details. Mitigation: suppress or genericize validation errors in production (avoid returning exact field suggestions), or enable strict error handling that does not leak schema specifics, and log detailed errors server-side only.", "evidence": "Error messages: \"Cannot query field \\\"completedd\\\" on type \\\"Todo\\\". Did you mean \\\"completed\\\"?\" and \"Cannot query field \\\"usernme\\\" on type \\\"User\\\". Did you mean \\\"username\\\"?\" (also: \"Field \\\"userId\\\" is not defined by type \\\"CreateTodoInput\\\".\")", "confidence": 0.95, "llm_analysis": {"is_vulnerable": true, "vulnerability_type": "field_suggestions", "severity": "MEDIUM", "confidence": 0.95, "evidence": "Error messages: \"Cannot query field \\\"completedd\\\" on type \\\"Todo\\\". Did you mean \\\"completed\\\"?\" and \"Cannot query field \\\"usernme\\\" on type \\\"User\\\". Did you mean \\\"username\\\"?\" (also: \"Field \\\"userId\\\" is not defined by type \\\"CreateTodoInput\\\".\")", "explanation": "The GraphQL API returns helpful 'Did you mean ...' suggestions in error messages that reveal actual field names in the schema (e.g., completed, username). This is a field_suggestions/information-disclosure issue: an attacker can use these suggestions to enumerate accurate schema field names and shape subsequent queries, facilitating more targeted data discovery or abuse. While this does not itself indicate SQLi, XSS, SSRF, or command injection, it increases attack surface by exposing internal schema details. Mitigation: suppress or genericize validation errors in production (avoid returning exact field suggestions), or enable strict error handling that does not leak schema specifics, and log detailed errors server-side only."}}]

simple_results: [{"detection_name": "SQL Injection (SQLi) Injection", "detection": "potential", "category": "Injection Attacks", "description": "SQL injection vulnerability detected - malicious SQL patterns found in response", "evidence": "Response status: 200, SQL patterns detected in response"}]

[{"detection_name": "Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) Injection", "detection": "potential", "category": "Injection Attacks", "description": "XSS injection vulnerability detected - malicious script patterns found in response", "evidence": "Response status: 200, XSS patterns detected in response data"}]
llm_results: [{"detection_name": "LLM: xss_injection", "detection": "vulnerable", "category": "Injection Attacks", "description": "The GraphQL response from createTodo contains an unescaped script tag in the title field: <script>alert('xss')</script>. This is clear evidence that user-supplied input is being returned verbatim. If a client (web page) inserts this title into the DOM without proper HTML-encoding or sanitization, it will execute as JavaScript (reflected/stored XSS). Exploitation depends on how the client renders this value, but the presence of raw <script> tags in API output constitutes a direct XSS risk. Recommended mitigations: properly escape/encode data before inserting into HTML, sanitize or validate input server-side, avoid inserting raw HTML into the DOM (e.g., avoid dangerouslySetInnerHTML), and deploy a strict Content-Security-Policy to reduce impact.", "evidence": "\"title\": \"<script>alert('xss')</script>\"", "confidence": 0.9, "llm_analysis": {"is_vulnerable": true, "vulnerability_type": "xss_injection", "severity": "HIGH", "confidence": 0.9, "evidence": "\"title\": \"<script>alert('xss')</script>\"", "explanation": "The GraphQL response from createTodo contains an unescaped script tag in the title field: <script>alert('xss')</script>. This is clear evidence that user-supplied input is being returned verbatim. If a client (web page) inserts this title into the DOM without proper HTML-encoding or sanitization, it will execute as JavaScript (reflected/stored XSS). Exploitation depends on how the client renders this value, but the presence of raw <script> tags in API output constitutes a direct XSS risk. Recommended mitigations: properly escape/encode data before inserting into HTML, sanitize or validate input server-side, avoid inserting raw HTML into the DOM (e.g., avoid dangerouslySetInnerHTML), and deploy a strict Content-Security-Policy to reduce impact."}}]

[{"detection_name": "HTML Injection", "detection": "potential", "category": "Injection Attacks", "description": "HTML injection vulnerability detected - HTML markup found in response", "evidence": "Response status: 200, HTML patterns detected in response data"}]
llm_results: [{"detection_name": "LLM: html_injection", "detection": "vulnerable", "category": "Injection Attacks", "description": "The GraphQL response returns unescaped HTML markup in the 'title' field (\"\"). This indicates the API is reflecting/storing raw HTML/JS content. If a client application injects this value into a web page DOM without proper encoding or sanitization, the payload will execute as script (onerror handler), resulting in an XSS (HTML injection) vulnerability. Because this came back from a createTodo mutation, it appears to be stored/reflected and can affect other users (persistent XSS). Mitigation: properly validate/encode output (HTML-escape content) or sanitize inputs, enforce Content Security Policy, and avoid inserting untrusted data into the DOM as HTML.", "evidence": "\"title\": \"\"", "confidence": 0.9, "llm_analysis": {"is_vulnerable": true, "vulnerability_type": "html_injection", "severity": "HIGH", "confidence": 0.9, "evidence": "\"title\": \"\"", "explanation": "The GraphQL response returns unescaped HTML markup in the 'title' field (\"\"). This indicates the API is reflecting/storing raw HTML/JS content. If a client application injects this value into a web page DOM without proper encoding or sanitization, the payload will execute as script (onerror handler), resulting in an XSS (HTML injection) vulnerability. Because this came back from a createTodo mutation, it appears to be stored/reflected and can affect other users (persistent XSS). Mitigation: properly validate/encode output (HTML-escape content) or sanitize inputs, enforce Content Security Policy, and avoid inserting untrusted data into the DOM as HTML."}}]

[{"detection_name": "LLM: Introspection", "detection": "safe", "category": "Injection Attacks", "description": "The GraphQL error message reveals schema-level information (type name 'Query' and that the field 'createTodo' is not present on it). While this is not a direct __schema introspection response, it constitutes schema information disclosure which can aid an attacker in mapping the API and discovering valid operations. This leakage is consistent with an introspection-related information disclosure issue. Impact is limited (no sensitive data returned), so severity is LOW. Mitigation: suppress detailed validation errors in production, disable GraphQL introspection queries if not required, and return generic error messages to avoid leaking schema details.", "evidence": "Error response: \"Cannot query field \\\"createTodo\\\" on type \\\"Query\\\".\" (GRAPHQL_VALIDATION_FAILED)", "confidence": 0.6, "llm_analysis": {"is_vulnerable": true, "vulnerability_type": "Introspection", "severity": "LOW", "confidence": 0.6, "evidence": "Error response: \"Cannot query field \\\"createTodo\\\" on type \\\"Query\\\".\" (GRAPHQL_VALIDATION_FAILED)", "explanation": "The GraphQL error message reveals schema-level information (type name 'Query' and that the field 'createTodo' is not present on it). While this is not a direct __schema introspection response, it constitutes schema information disclosure which can aid an attacker in mapping the API and discovering valid operations. This leakage is consistent with an introspection-related information disclosure issue. Impact is limited (no sensitive data returned), so severity is LOW. Mitigation: suppress detailed validation errors in production, disable GraphQL introspection queries if not required, and return generic error messages to avoid leaking schema details."}}]

llm_results: [{"detection_name": "LLM: field_suggestions", "detection": "safe", "category": "Unknown", "description": "The GraphQL error responses include automatic 'Did you mean ...?' suggestions exposing exact field names in the schema (e.g., 'completed', 'username'). This is a field_suggestions information disclosure issue: it leaks schema details and valid field names to unauthenticated clients, which aids schema enumeration and targeted probing. The issue is not a direct data leak or injection, so severity is low, but it increases attack surface. Mitigations: disable or suppress suggestion text in error responses, return generic validation errors, restrict GraphQL introspection in production, or log detailed errors server-side only.", "evidence": "Errors: \"Cannot query field \\\"completedd\\\" on type \\\"Todo\\\". Did you mean \\\"completed\\\"?\" and \"Cannot query field \\\"usernme\\\" on type \\\"User\\\". Did you mean \\\"username\\\"?\"", "confidence": 0.95, "llm_analysis": {"is_vulnerable": true, "vulnerability_type": "field_suggestions", "severity": "LOW", "confidence": 0.95, "evidence": "Errors: \"Cannot query field \\\"completedd\\\" on type \\\"Todo\\\". Did you mean \\\"completed\\\"?\" and \"Cannot query field \\\"usernme\\\" on type \\\"User\\\". Did you mean \\\"username\\\"?\"", "explanation": "The GraphQL error responses include automatic 'Did you mean ...?' suggestions exposing exact field names in the schema (e.g., 'completed', 'username'). This is a field_suggestions information disclosure issue: it leaks schema details and valid field names to unauthenticated clients, which aids schema enumeration and targeted probing. The issue is not a direct data leak or injection, so severity is low, but it increases attack surface. Mitigations: disable or suppress suggestion text in error responses, return generic validation errors, restrict GraphQL introspection in production, or log detailed errors server-side only."}}]
